It markets itself as an adventure camera and claims to be freeze proof yet it has lithium ion batteries, which drain like crazy when they get cold. The product manual even acknowledges this and recommends keeping the camera warm and in a pocket close to the skin. I took it skiing at Alta ski area on a day that was about 15 degrees. I kept it in my pocket and it was fine all day. However, I'm worried about what happens on multiday backcountry trips. How do I keep it charged? If I have an extra battery and it isn't in my pocket all day and night it is likely to drain. I can't take the charger unless I get the big huge GoPro solar panels with an inverter. Since it doesn't support USB charging I can't get a cheap AA battery pack that functions as a charger. In my opinion this is not a good multi-day camera due to the power supply.* Controls feel "Trinkety". The controls are plastic and feel like they were made from dime store plastic. It kind of makes the camera feel cheap. They do function OK.* Clunky controls and menus. The more you dive into the features and settings the more ridiculous it becomes. I'm the type of person who uses the controls and menus on a camera and I'd give the person who designed the menus and controls a C- grade. I guess they work, but for example it takes 3 clicks to delete a photo.* Boots up quickly. This is good because it is ready for action quickly. It's also good because there is no way to keep the camera "on" and have the display off.* Picture Review There is a mode to display the picture instantly after you take the shot but it only stays on the screen for like a second. On other cameras I liked the ability to select a longer auto display after the shot.* A class 6 SD memory card is recommended because you are recording HD movie. You'll probably want a 4GB or bigger card. Nikon only recommends SanDisk, Lexar, Panasonic and one other brand I'm forgetting.* The lens itself is covered by a piece of glass. The manual says it is possible that the internal glass surface might fog. They say "this is not a defect". The remedy they give is to go back to a place with a stable temperature, open the side door and see if it clears up. How am I supposed to do that in the backcountry? Fogging and condensation in the backcountry is due to extremes in temperature and moisture. I did not experience this when using the camera. I guess it is a pro and a con. It is easy to wipe off, but you are shooting through an additional surface which can pick up glare.* The camera is lightweight and compact* The action control navigation feature might actually be nice when you are wearing bulky gloves. I found it a little weird* Great Under water mode. I thought this might be its best feature. I was surprised at the quality of the photos and video it took under water. It might be cool to get the camera in the water as your buddy is reeling in a big fish on his fly rod. I took lots of pictures in rivers and tidepools and the ocean and it worked well. You can take it to 33 feet depth. I wish it were rated to go to double that for scuba diving.* Shock Resistant: I really like the idea that it is shock resistant. In the back country I tend to be hard on cameras. I have broken at least 3 because I dropped them or they were attached to a tripod that got bumped or blew over in the wind. I did not test or accidentally test this feature.Video ModeI was really disappointed in the video mode.* Banding was observed when shooting indoors and outdoors. There was also a lot of that phenomenon where you get a pixelated edge on your subject. The manual says this may occur in the presence of fluorescent and other types of lighting. I observied it outdoors in ideal lighting. It is very annoying and negates the purpose of having an HD camera. It also has problems with autofocus when the subject is moving.* High Speed Mode: I was intrigued by the ability to record HS video (with a fast frame rate of up to 240 fps. And thus enabling smooth slow motion playback). There are lots of times this would be nice. Like when a friend is doing a backflip off a waterfall into a pool of water. It works OK. The super slo mo 240 fps mode is in VGA and requires ideal lighting or it comes out dark. One cool feature they thought of is the ability to have the camera start regular speed filming and at the opportune moment when you want to capture slow motion you hit the "ok" button and it films in HS until you hit "ok" again and then it goes back to regular speed.* The zoom speed is fixed. Thus you can't do a slow zoom vs a fast zoom. I know this is not intended to be a motion studio quality camera, but just be aware of what you are getting. In general I'd describe the zoom as fast and abrupt. I didn't like this.* It has a small light (emphasis on small) that can help brighten the filming. I guess it is better than nothing.* Cuts Wind noise: It has a feature that cuts wind noise while filming. I tried it out and it seemed to help a little. In the backcountry on exposed ridges high wind is common.GPS ModeIt has very basic GPS functions. The controls are very clunky. Having it turned on sucks your battery. It does seem to pick up the satellites well. It's cool to have GPS data recorded in your pics.DigiscopingIf this camera had functioned well for digiscoping I would have kept it. It almost worked--it sort of worked. As expected with most cameras, vingetting was apparent when initially attached with a the Swarovski DCA adaptor. The vingetting did disappear when I zoomed all the way to the max optical range--5x and the scope was on it's lowest power-20x. Interestingly, the vignetting started when I cranked up the spotting scope power to around 45X. At 60X it was quite noticeable. I thought it was awesome that the camera comes with a 40.5mm adaptor that can be used with filters of that size. It clips on over the camera lens and I was able to get a step-up adaptor so it would fit on my 52mm spotting scope attachment. The autofocus at times seemed a little tripped out than other cameras I've used when digiscoping. It would blur in and out trying to figure out what I was shooting at. It did take excellent videos and photos when I had the scope on 20X and the camera zoomed to 5X. Because the camera is light it seemed to hang fine.Picture QualityI wasn't blown away with the consistency of the photo quality. To be sure it took some excellent photos, but then it would totally blow some other shots. I'll defer to other reviews on this.* 16 Megapixels means you can "posterize" your trip or even get shots for a magazine.* Panorama Mode: I was excited about this mode--but only half of it really worked. It has this "easy panorama mode where you can just pan the camera and it will instantly create a panorama. I works OK at best. It sometimes leaves the stitches a little weird. It also has a manual stitch mode that works well.In summary I wanted to love this camera but in the end I think it only partially lived up to it's bill as an adventure camera. The problematic power supply issues, poor HD video quality, terrible controls, inconsistent photo quality, and less than ideal digiscoping functionality were not enought to outweigh the positives of underwater mode, and high mega pixels. I hope my discussion of the details will help other backcountry users know what they are getting into if they buy this. Unfortunately I feel like I don't know what else to turn to right now.

Reviews.Title: Awsome Nikon AW100 (20111212) Update 20120801
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "NoClue-Really!"
Reviews.Content: UPDATE 20120801 -  Amazon would not allow a separate update for a similar product purchase so I have to update this review ...I just bought the replacement for the AW100 that rests on the bottom of the Pacific.  It is ORANGE (Nikon COOLPIX AW100 16 MP CMOS Waterproof Digital Camera with GPS and Full HD 1080p Video (ORANGE)).I am not all that "keen" on Orange; however, the price was $40 less (now $268) than the original Black. It takes good pictures.  I say this because the original black unit would have difficulty sometimes taking a closeUp picture.  The "new" orange unit works near and far.  Now, I have to put it in water to make sure it is waterProof for its up-and-coming adventure.Oh, I have upgraded the AW100 to five (5) stars.  For several reasons:  1)  I bought another unit; 2) The orange works in my mix-and-notMatch world; 3) Maybe, just maybe, it will be easier to spot if it gets away from me; and, 4) It was $40 less expensive.I continue to recommend this product!***********************************************************20120322 ... The Nikon aw100 (BLACK) actually went to Hawaii as planned.  It took pictures on O'Ahu, and then on Hawai'i.  It was also supposed to be used on Maui.  It was a great camera.  It did almost 100% of what I thought it should.  It took surprising panorama shots.  It took amazing underwater pictures at the sea horse farm.  It took wonderful pictures in two lagoons while snorkling to approximate depths of 20 to 30 feet without any leakage.  It even got pictures of my spouse snorkling.  Then the camera did the most unspeakable thing.  It became a $400 "disposable" camera when it untethered itself and went to the bottom of the Pacific.  It was missed only when the Zodiac stopped in the third lagoon.It is a long shot to ask, "If anyone locates the camera I would place no claim; however, I would greatly appreciate getting the 16gb SDHC card that has many pictures that can never be replaced."Now, for the next adventure where the "camera" will not run away?-------------------------------------------------------------20111212 ... For some reason I always need another camera.  The Nikon AW100 will fill a niche I have for something that can get dunked.  It will be a good companion to the Nikon S1000pj (the one that projects the image on a wall).Another important piece is that both the AW100 and the S1000pj use the same EN-EL12 battery.  Speaking of that, you just have to get the TWO EN-EL12 Replacement Battery (1050 mAh) + Battery Charger FOR Nikon CoolPix S1000pj / S610 / S610c / S620 / S630 / S640 / S70 / S710 / S8000 Digita ... offering here on Amazon.com since these two cameras can consume a lot of batteryJuice!  I got four (4) units of the above mentioned charger and got eight (8) EN-EL12 batteries as well as four car adapters and four wall chargers for under $35 TOTAL - "Oh, and they work, too!" which really surprised me.There is a lot about the AW100 I have not used.  My first curiosity was the battery.  I just wanted to see what the maximum burn might be.  I turned on all options (at maximum) and tinkered with everything to use as much batteryJuice as I could.  The result was something like 76 pictures - "Acceptable" to me.I inserted a Transcend 32 GB Class SDHC 10 Flash Memory Card TS32GSDHC10E into the AW100.  4,000 plus pictures at maximum resolution for under $40.The GPS.  Seem to sensitive enough to work inside most buildings even where DeLorme and Garmin GPS units cannot get signal.  The map is very general and is really useful, for me, for GeoCaching.  To get the coordinates from the jpg image requires Photoshop or other software that can access this meta data.  One curiosity is the possible map updates.  This feature shows in the menu; however, so far I have not been able to find out much more about it.The Compass.  The neighbors thought I was a little confused/touched as I stood in my front yard waiving this small black object in a figure-eight motion as the snow fell around me.  For some reason I felt that I needed to be able to get a good compassReading in my yard in the snow to learn how well the "first" pictures might look (BTW, they looked good if I might say so!).The Lens position.  The position of the lens is where one can take marvelous pictures of parts of one's fingers.  I have a whole set of them that I might put on display in a gallery?The Camera with Heart.  The AW100 has numerous settings.  When you get the camera you will see this icon (camera with heart) on the screen.  It basicially means the camera will take a picture - results are mostly surprisingly good.The Camera without Heart.  I mostly use this setting.The Panorama (sp?).  It is most curious.  I am more accustomed to the larger images available in the Sony A900 and the like that are stitched using something like Photoshop.  The AW100 does a grand job of creating a panorama.  Now, the camera is a little to smart AND you have to do the way the developers intended which I remain a little uncertain about the 360-deg version.  I have gotten insulted using the 180-deg version by being informed I am not doing it right.  You can only go in one direction with either horizontal or vertical movement - BUT, not both.  The end result when I do the right thing is a strip photo that seems a whole lot better than I thought that I would get.Up Close.  I like microPhotography.  This camera does a good job.Low Light.  I am not certain that the camera was responsible, more so than the operator, when taking low light photographs.  The camera seemed to have a difficult time focusing even with the assist light that is built into the camera for these situations.Light Assist.  This is an annoying light that is disruptive because I have not found the setting to keep it extinguished when I do not want it startling the photoObject or announcing that a photograph will be taken.Opening the Housing.  The battery, SD card, USB and HDMI connectors are located behind a door that is sorta a mess for big fingers to open since the button on the top must be pressed and then a counterClockwise turn must be done to get the door open.  The space is "real" tight and I did find that some SDHC cards were not all that easy to extract or to determine if properly seated.  If this happens, just remove the battery and it is easier to slip a fingerNail into the SD card crease for extraction.Menu.  The menu is not the best Nikon has offered.  I have finally located most of the features I think should be available.  Some I am still seeking.Documentation.  The userGuide and userManual are a poorExcuse and an exercise in futility.  They follow the typical mentality of "trial and mistake" to learn how to meaningfully use the camera features.Waterproof.  I was going to take the camera into the bathtub to do some underWater shooting of a rubberDucky.  I was advised that this was offensive to the rubberDucky and possibly illegal and probably an issue of privacy so I will have to wait until I am in the ocean.Strap.  It really makes no sense to include a nonWaterProof strap with a camera that is to be used underwater.  I do not have time to get a waterProof strap so I will have to makeDo with some fishingLine.  Oh yes, there was as sorta piece-of-string that was supposed to be used with the camera in the water.  I really need a strap that can just stay connected to the camera so when I fall out-of-the-boat I do not have to spend a whole lot of time trying to change to the waterProofStrap before I hit the water ("Oh yea, where, in this instance do I put the nonWaterProof strap?).Pictures.  The camera takes great pictures in a snow setting where other cameras straight-out-of-the-box fail.  Night photographs are a little iffy.  In-the-water pictures have not been tried, yet!Zoom.  It also has digital zoom.  I find, as with most digital zoom, it adds more noise to the picture than the implied benefit from the apparentCloseness provided by the inCamera crop.  It might be okay for those that do not have something like Photoshop.  The lens zoom was adequate and allowed me to capture deer in the snow at some 100 yards that will, of course, need Photoshop.Slideshow.  I am using slideShow two ways.  The first is to display the individual pictures that have been collected on the SD card.  It works okay.  I usually do not use a camera for this purpose.  I would much rather shoot pictures and then get back to the 27" colorCorrected monitor and photoshop at some later time.  The second part of the slideShow is used with panoramas.  In this case, the picture is moved smoothly across the entire vista of the scene.  A bit impressive but lacks the usefulness of portability to be able to share with friends.Buttons.  Like buttons on anything small if big fingers are involved.  "Ya just has to deal with it!"Overall Impression.  The Nikon AW100 hasn't leaked yet (of course not, I have not put it into the water).  It has taken an assortment of pictures that I think exercise its capabilities.  I am impressed.  So, let's learn how well it does underwater.  More on this soon.

Reviews.Title: Its just slightly waterproof
Reviews.Author: bmoag "ae"
Reviews.Content: On dry land it is an adequate if overpriced digicam. Underwater is a whole different matter. Mine worked once. and the quality of stills and video was quite adequate. Ddn't change anything. Next day the camera stopped working and the LCD on the back is full of water. This was at a depth of however long my arms are, which is a lot less than the rated thirty feet, I believe. There was no water in the chamber under the door which is where you might expect the leak to be. Sadly the camera is  not adequately sealed for what is advertised to do. The one star is higher than a device of this price deserves that is clearly nothing like what it is advertised to be. I doubt it would stand up to use in light rain. I forgot to mention that the geotagging doesn't work at all, at least it didn't on this unit. Now to test Nikon repair service . . .

Reviews.Title: great underwater camera
Reviews.Author: brad
Reviews.Content: I read many reviews of all available underwater cameras and they all were shown to leak from the cheapest to the most expensive, then I saw this one come on the market and I waited and read it's reviews and no leaks so I bought one.  I dive alot and hate the bulky housing most underwater cameras use but this one works great down to 35ft any deeper and it just flashes "memory card incorrect for this camera" but it is great I now use it as my only vacation camera because it works great on land too and if I jump in the pool or it rains or whatever NO PROBLEM it is meant for it.  Really who wants to carry around two cameras on vacation this serves every function as long as you are not trying to shoot professional photos the quality of the pics is great.

Reviews.Title: AWESOME
Reviews.Author: Brian S.
Reviews.Content: I am super picky about cameras and viewed a lot of footage on YouTube from the average user who took this camera on trips.  I always felt the average person is a far better judge of a product than a business is (except consumer reports of course).  I took this camera on it's first use during a Caribbean 7-day cruise.  With constant pictures (max size / quality), average amount of flashes used, and HD video repeatedly being taken; I averaged two batteries per day - starting around 7am and recording / picturing up until 11pm daily.  The second battery was about 1/4 left by 11pm.For underwater use - the quality was unbelievable.  I took it on a couple snorkeling dives and had it recording (HD Video on underwater mode) before jumping into the water.  Shock-absorbing quality was awesome as it got a very hard workout during the dives, jumping, and knocking around.  The video recording excellent sound in and out of water without the out-of-water sound being distorted at all (no shaking needed to clear anything out).  Waterproofing held up to 30 feet diving and not a single drop was seen inside during anytime I swapped out batteries or memory cards.  Nighttime video was always very good still during the multiple stage shows and trips around the ship.Picture taking was quick and not delayed heavy as with previous CoolPix models that I have used.  Power-up was also quick and made it very easy to use this camera when a picture was needed right now and not 15 seconds from now.I've used the camera a great deal since the cruise (couple months ago now) and still not a single problem has occurred.I am VERY happy with this camera and couldn't believe it actually turned out to be as good as the product description led itself out to be!

Reviews.Title: Pretty good little water camera
Reviews.Author: MonicaMole
Reviews.Content: Got is for my husband as an early Christmas present, we were going to Roatan (Bay Islands,Honduras) and we got great underwater pictures as well as sunsets, people and the last day there, under an awful storm, we got some great video and including the wind effect!  Its easy to use, small and yet it takes pics/videos as a much sofisticated camera, highly recomend it!

Reviews.Title: Just not up to to snuff...
Reviews.Author: Edom
Reviews.Content: It sounds good on paper, but the responsiveness and image quality is just not that good.  I played with high ISO shots, and then I played with Lumix TS3, and the Sony TX10; I think it's embarassing when generic electronic companies do better than the photo-dedicated giant like Nikon (and all the backlit-cmos mumbo-jumbo is not helping out).  Aside from better high-iso shots from sony and panny, the lens actually opens up a little more on sony and panasonic (f/3.5, and f/3.3, respectively), whereas on the Nikon it's f/3.9 (even this little bit makes quite a bit of difference in the dark).  And both Sony and Panasonic feel more responsive, when focusing and taking a picture...  There are many cons and pros to all these cameras, but the Nikon consistently looses out on the actual ability to take pictures.  The focus is softer than on the other cameras, and the jpg's have this "smudgy" overprocessed look.  It's an OK camera with GREAT specs; but, after playing with the competition, I don't consider the Nikon's bringing to the table a worthwhile competitor.  Interestingly, Canon is also not participating in this waterproof camera game (effectively).  I ended up going with Sony for its smaller size, even though I'm not a fan of the touchscreen.  Panasonic is also a VERY GOOD alternative.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Camera for Outdoor Use
Reviews.Author: Alan Montgomery
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera a few days now and have been very impressed with the tests I've put it through thus far.  This camera does everything Nikon says it will and does them all wonderfully.Overall BuildThis is a small camera in your hands which is a good and bad thing.  It's great because it means it's easy to slip in your pants or shirt pocket and always keep with you.  It weighs little enough that you hardly notice it's there.  I see where some people could see this as an issue because the buttons on it are very small in order to have the back LCD as large as possible.  It does not feel cheap even though it's made out of plastic and although I don't plan on doing a drop test, I am confident it would survive a drop from chest high.Picture QualityWith an 8GB SD card I don't see a reason to shoot at any other setting than the highest resolution, so all my playing around with it was done at this setting.  The JPEGs that come out look great.  The images are sharp, have good color and the auto whitebalance has done an amazing job.  The main thing I was worried about was having to do difficult WB corrections after the fact if it wasn't right on with the WB, but so far it has been spot on in full sun shots, shady shots, indoor with incandescent and indoor with fluorescent lights.  I honestly think the 16MP is a little overkill, but will keep shooting at full resolution as I don't know when I'll need those extra pixels.  Lastly, low light shooting has definitely exceeded my expectations.  I thought with a sensor as small as this one there would be lots of noise in the final result but even at the higher ISO levels the pictures are very clear and useable.VideoI don't really plan on using this for video too much but have tested it out nonetheless.  It is very smooth while shooting at 1080p and looks great when run to my TV to view it.  The microphones pick up the noises very well and even have a setting that reduces wind noise (I tested by blowing on the microphone while recording).  To shoot video you don't have to change modes or anything - you just press the red circle button on the back and you're off.Button Placement/MenuEverything seems to get in the right place as far as buttons go.  Most can be reached with either your right thumb or right index finger while you're holding it up to shoot without adjusting, although if you are a lefty you will need to get used to holding it in your right hand.  I also shoot a Nikon d5100 and had no trouble figuring out what everything did without looking at the instruction manual, so if you've used a Nikon in the past few years this should be a breeze.  The menu is fairly uncomplicated and not overloaded with useless features.  It is quick to get to the setting I want without too many annoying clicks.  This is important to me as I had missing shots while I fumble with the buttons.Vibration ReductionI tested this out by holding the camera at arms length with one hand while shooting some test shots.  Even from the LCD I could tell the image was doing a lot less shaking than my hand was, and was very impressed by the pictures when they came out.  This will definitely come in handy on the boat.Auto-FocusHaving not used a point and shoot in a few year, I was very pleased with how far the autofocus has come.  It quickly locks on to an object, highlights the object and will keep it in focus even if you start swinging the camera around.  Going from objects ~1 foot away to 30 feet away has been focused quickly and accurately.  No complaints here.Water-ProofnessThe main reason I got this camera is so I could take it out with me when I go fishing.  This means the first chance I got, I took this camera in a pool to start testing it out.  It worked as expected, shooting at the 10 foot deep end of the pool with no problem.  The color correction for shooting underwater was also quite effective.  After taking some test shots, I put the camera in my pocket for the rest of the time in the pool just to keep it submerged for as long as possible.  After a quick towel off out of the pool, it looked good as new.  The battery/SD card door has a foolproof way of shutting and remaining watertight so unless I puncture something I'm not worried about water getting in there.GPSI have loved the performance of the GPS even when indoors.  This is something that will be very useful when I either go fishing or go out in the woods and want to take a picture of something that is in a location I want to come back to.  The GPS data is written to the metadata so I can punch it in googlemaps after I get home to see where things were.  It also has an electronic compass which is handy for a few reasons and has worked great so far.FlashIt works and it lights things up.  I've sort of grown to love to hate flashes for snapshot while using my dSLR so I try not to use it often.  It is significantly better than some of the old point and shoots I've used, so in a pinch I will rely on it.Battery LifeDon't let the tiny battery fool you - it lasts a long time.  After the initial charge, I've spent close to an hour just going through all the menus playing with things, testing out the GPS, taking dozens of pictures and videos and reviewing them on the camera after the fact and am still above 50%.  I couldn't imagine a situation where I would feel the need to purchase or bring a second battery along unless I was going to be out of civilization for a week or so.I would highly recommend this camera to anyone who is looking for an outdoor/waterproof camera, or someone who needs a slightly more durable camera due to butterfingers.

Reviews.Title: best tough camera
Reviews.Author: ckinser
Reviews.Content: Just got this camera last week, It takes great pictures even when there is not much light. It feels well built and very compact. the panaorama is the easiest i have ever used. Processing speed is fast with no or little shutter lag. Very cool that this will shoot slow motion video. The gps function with a world map is very cool especially for those traveling. If you are using the gps you might want to buy extra batteries as it makes the camera less miserly with it on. it is nice that it has seperate caqmera and video buttons and a movie light is also nice as it will give some good fill lighting. All in all a great camera with lots of features. The zoom is only 5x but that is a good thing. the new megazoom cameras do not give sharp pictures which is why i picked this camera over the L 120.

Reviews.Title: Durable but severely lacking
Reviews.Author: Ben Barton
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera with the intention of bringing it on a trip and otherwise using it in active (like wet and abusive) outdoor conditions.Likes:*Durable - Build is solid and I banged it around a bit with no ill effects while swimming through a cave. No problems there.*Waterproof - Fortunately, I never had any of the water intrusion problems so many other reviewers had. I used it in pouring rain, while soaking in some hot springs and I did swim with it, but did not dive. I'd say the max depth my camera experienced is shallower than 6 feet.*GPS - Love this feature. The GPS seemed to be very accurate, almost a little too picky about being accurate as I touch on in the dislikes section below. I love having my pictures tagged with location data and consider this a valuable feature.*Compass - Very nice to have. Kept me from getting lost a couple of times when I needed a general idea of direction. The camera also tags the photo with compass data, so you get to see where the camera was pointing when the picture was taken.*Video - HD video is nice.*Quick startup - I was impressed with the time it took to power up and take the first picture. It's a shame about that second one though. (see below)Dislikes:*Lens fogs up nearly *EVERY TIME* I pull it out to take pictures - This is my number one frustration. Yes, I know Nikon has something to say about this. Sitting on the top of Mt. St. Helens getting pummeled by wind and blowing snow while waiting 15 min for the camera to (maybe!) decide to un-fog while is no fun at all. Getting wildlife to cooperate and wait for my camera to be ready doesn't work very well. Sunsets/sunrises don't stay put either. Simply, this is an unacceptable drawback.*Poor image quality - Taking pictures at 16MP was pointless because of all the lens fogging, sensor / JPEG noise, poor autofocus, lens smudges etc. My iPhone took better pictures.*Autofocus was inconsistent - I could never trust it to get an in-focus picture the first time. Always remember rule #2 from the movie Zombieland: Double-tap.*2nd picture was slow - Speaking of double-tap. It was frustrating that it would take a second or two to take the next picture. Despite using a class 10 card.*Horrible battery life - I could hope that the battery lasted about a day's use. Yes, I used it with the GPS and compass on nearly all the time. No, I don't want to turn it off, the GPS is my one of my favorite features and a major reason I picked this camera. I think it would be helpful if the screen's backlight would go dark after some time of being idle. A larger battery would help more.*Charger unsuitable for travel - The size of the charger itself wasn't too bad. The bad part is that it comes with this 6ft cord. Combined with the terrible battery life, this is a larger drawback than it would be for other cameras.*USB cable - Speaking of dumb cords. This camera uses a different type USB cable. So you'll be bringing along yet another cable if you want to retrieve the pictures from the camera. Also, the camera can't charge via this port.*Slow GPS - If the camera was powered on say, 50 miles from its last known location, acquiring an new position took FOREVER. Meanwhile, the screen's backlight would be going full blast and the battery would be running down.*Picky GPS - If I had a locked-in position, then stepped below something that blocked the signal for 2 seconds, it would decide not to tag my photos with location. C'mon guys, I didn't move that far in a couple of seconds.*No orientation sensor - Hope you like rotating your photos 90deg in post.*No lens cover - Lens would get smudged in my pocket. I was always wiping the lens whenever I had something clean and dry to wipe with. Due to the nature of my trips, I frequently didn't have anything clean/dry, so I was stuck with lots of poor photos as a result. A friend's old waterproof Olympus had a retracting lens protector. It would be nice to have something like that, but I imagine there are durability trade offs.*Action Control frustrations - I could never get this to work in a way that I could predict and the camera would just decide to do random stuff. Also, there was no way to turn it off for picture viewing, so the camera would usually switch to a different photo when I handed the camera to another person.In conclusion, the things I like about this camera don't have anything to do with being a camera and I dislike all the camera-like attributes. When compared to my old Canon SD770 that it was to replace, it falls down in every category except durability and video. I think I'll be getting rid of this one and looking at Olympus or Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Broken after using it 6 days
Reviews.Author: SuperHijitus
Reviews.Content: I bought it exclusively for my trip to the beach, when it worked was a 'just fine' camera, but all the sudden just after the 2nd battery charge ran out, recharged it and put it back, the camera stopped capturing any images.All the features/internal mechanisms look like were working but the screen was pitch black.The seller washed its hands and referred me to Nikon Repair Centre. What a bad customer service.Not recommended

Reviews.Title: Buy it for water/abusing, nothing else
Reviews.Author: DC Machead "DC Machead"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera in hopes that it could serve as a "backup" camera for when I didn't want to carry around my DSLR. It's a nice camera for daytime use/well-lit conditions, and use in water...but that's it. I took it along to go trick-or-treating last night and the pictures it took were awful.The biggest peeve I've got is the lag time between pressing the button and when the shot is taken. If you've got kids and want to get pictures of them, you'll miss a lot of shots with this camera. This camera is absolutely dreadful in low-light conditions. My iPhone takes better pictures in low-light conditions.Bottom line, if you want a camera to abuse and take in water, this is it. If you're looking for a good all-around camera and water-proofness is NOT a critical feature, keep looking.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Jamie
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for our vacation.  It brought us a lifetime of memories!  We brought it in the ocean when we snorkled - it took great photos AND video!  My son recorded a video as he went down the water slide - so cool!  This camera made the vacation!

Reviews.Title: A phenomenal camera! (So far.)
Reviews.Author: Song
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for a trip to Belize where I spent a little over a week doing field research on the patch reef. I took my camera in the water with me every day, multiple trips a day and for hours at a time. It worked beautifully! I am especially impressed with the quality of the videos - they were far better than those taken by friends with other underwater cameras.I've always been a cannon person, but once I figured out all of the buttons, I found this camera to be well set up and quite easy to use underwater. It also take beautiful photographs out of the water.The only thing this camera doesn't have is a great zoom, but the benefits WAY outweigh that factor. You can drop this camera in the dirt and then just rinse it off. It's ok if your camera's in your backpack when your waterbottle leaks. You can drop it in the snow or the sand and have no problems. Just keep an eye on the o-ring around the battery/chip door and make sure you don't open it until it's all the way dry. I also put mine in rice after my trip to the tropics, just to make sure it was thoroughly dried out after so much time in the ocean.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Working hard-15
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera a week ago for my trip to the Bahamas. It has been fantastic so far. It has a quick shutter and holds still better than I do :) I really wanted it for the underwater adventure that I did. I submerged it in 20' deep water and it' stayed sealed so no water got in at all. I was very surprised. The quality is also spectacular for a 16 mp 5x optical zoom. I'd have to say I am impressed. If you're rough on cameras like I am then this is the perfect camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Not a waterproof camera
Reviews.Author: Sebastian
Reviews.Content: I bought the AW100 camera on the Sydney's airport duty free on july of the present year. I have been using it without any problems, and taking it into the water, paying attention to all the warnings and instruction from the owner's manual. Not even a month after purchased the camera stopped working.In the beginning, the screen would shut off after taking a picture, and after a few minutes more, the screen was always black. The "on" indicator in the button is on but the screen is simply black. Once I pressed the record button the screen started working, but on any other case the screen is dead.As Im not Aussie, and I was traveling, sent an email to nikon australia to see what it can be done. In the beginning they reply me and told me to fix it on an autorized service and they would pay for it.  After going to the technical service in Vietnam, Thailand AND FINLAND they all told me that water has leaked in, that that was a MANUFACTURE PROBLEM (i.e. A KNOWN FAILURE) and that they couldn't fix it because they never did. They always give a new camera but in my case they couldn't cuz I bought it in another country. After seeing this technical supports and sending all the info to my contact from nikon australia, he never reply again.I have tried calling and sending and sending emails but they just not reply.So, summarised, AW100 is not waterproof and they will do what is in their power to not respond

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof
Reviews.Author: Stacey V
Reviews.Content: Only reason I purchased this particular point and shoot was for waterproof capabilities.  Had a once in a lifetime experience of visiting the Great Barrier Reef for snorkeling (less than 10m) and the camera leaked with water in it.  Needless to say when I needed the camera most to capture reef pics, it failed miserably.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Book Reader "Book Reader"
Reviews.Content: Before you take this camera out, underwater, etc - please read the manual, either online or the one that came with the camera.  I see where about 2/3rds of the complaints about this camera could have been avoided if you'd have managed to read the manual.The GPS file needs updating too, just like your car GPS does!Google the term: Nikon A-GPS Update File Download to locate the file for download please.  It's from the Nikon Library site!Just make sure you are getting the A-GPS Update for the AW100 (says so in the description) and not an update for another model camera!!I'm very happy with this camera and it has proven itself to me already.Also, a nice travel type charger (with 2 extra batteries) can be had here:Wasabi Power Battery and Charger Kit for Nikon EN-EL12 and Nikon Coolpix AW100, AW100s, P300, S70, S630, S640, S1000pj, S1100pj, S1200pj, S6000, S6100, S6150, S6200, S8000, S8100, S8200, S9100I'd also suggest getting a Chums Camera Float (wristband type)Chums Waterproof Camera FloatThe best case I've found so far is by USA Gear.  It's better than the LowePro Dublin 20 because the USA Gear case has a little zippered compartment on the front with will hold 2 batteries and an additional SD chip!  The LowePro was just too snug!USA GEAR Neo-Cushion Portable Carrying Camera Case for Nikon Coolpix S1200PJ , AW100 , S8100 , S8200 , S6200 , S6300 , S9100 , S9300 , L26 and More Nikon Digital CamerasHave fun with your new camera, but for heck's sake, read the manual first!

Reviews.Title: Average performance, useless bells and whistles
Reviews.Author: MARWAN ISMAIL
Reviews.Content: Just came back from a week long Florida vacation where this camera was my back up. My D90 started acting up so I ended up using the AW100 as my primary. I don't know how other reviewers praise its "great" pictures and video. It is neither. The pictures were dull in color, the focus inacurate, the sharpness inadequate and the video sucked. Even underwater pictures were mediocre at best. While I am not a fan of compact cameras but I do expect stellar performance for such a price. I think my iphone takes better pictures. I think it is the GPS gadget that raised its price compared to other cameras but I have no need for it. (I already have more GPS devices than I know what to do with from my car, my phone, the ipad and maybe the toaster has one too!).I returned this camera for a refund and I am looking for another good waterproof back up with decent picture quality and a reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Would give it 0 stars if I could.
Reviews.Author: Kitty Hooligan
Reviews.Content: Yikes.  I have a range of cameras both DSLR and compacts.  I have an old beater that's still kicking and despite being four years old its photos are far better.It must be a lemon.  Not a single photo was in focus let alone sharp.  I tried all the different settings.  The white balance is off too.Movie zoom makes a sound like a loud purring cat, which is recorded for prosperity.I took photos late afternoon with plenty of sun, lighting was perfect, colors saturated.  What the camera captured looked like a grey day, almost sunset.Really wanted to like this camera.:^(

Reviews.Title: Great Shallow Dive Camera
Reviews.Author: T. Thompson
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a scuba trip to Grand Cayman and Cozumel.Pros:Very easy to use- good manualTook the camera on my second dive of each day to a maximum depth of 52 feet ( yes the rating is only for 33 feet).Another Diver had the same camera and had taken it to 65+feetHD video was amazing.Camera pictures were perfect.Built in flash provided plenty of light for subject 2.5 feet and closer.Great price at under $270Cons:When on surface would sometimes stay in underwater mode.At depth I noticed slight indentation in center of LCD screen- I won't be taking it and deeper than 55ishNeed to provide your own underwater wrist bandGPS will not work indoorsGPS features lacking

Reviews.Title: tough!
Reviews.Author: Jon doe
Reviews.Content: I work in a lot of harsh environments, so i own a lot of severe duty electrionics items. This is not as tough as say a tough book computer, but it's pretty solid. Takes really nice pix and videos too.

Reviews.Title: Good image quality, poor battery life and auto focus
Reviews.Author: David Wilton
Reviews.Content: The Nikon AW100 is a nice looking camera that produces very good images. However, it suffers horribly from two vexing problems. First, the battery life on this thing is extremely poor if you use the GPS, compass or maps features. If you plan to go on long hikes or camping with it, be sure to bring along lots of extra batteries. You'll be lucky to get more than an hour or two out of one charge with average to heavy use with maps, GPS and the compass features turned on. Second, focus is terrible. This thing takes forever to focus and often fires off before it achieves anything but a blur. For a camera meant for the outdoors, it craps out on a pretty important aspect of a point and shoot: reliable focus on anything but landscapes. Nikon has produced a pricey mediocre first effort in the tough camera segment. Might be better to take along a cheaper, less tough alternative and just be careful with it rather than rely on the AW100.

Reviews.Title: Broke first time underwater!  Buyer beware!
Reviews.Author: blamo
Reviews.Content: Nikon claims that this is a waterproof camera but the very first time I used it underwater water leaked inside and the camera broke.  I followed all of the water usage protocol and procedures listed in the user manual, only using the camera in a few feet of water in a pool for about 30 minutes.  The camera showed signs of malfunctioning immediately in the water when each time I turned it vertically the screen would black out; it would only show an image if the camera was held horizontally.  I'm not sure if that's a settings issue or not, but that never happened when I took pictures vertically outside of the water.  When I returned home from the pool and opened the battery compartment there was water inside despite making sure that the compartment was sealed shut.  From that point on, the camera would turn on but the screen remained black and it was unable to take pictures.I contacted Nikon about the issue and the only response from them was to send it in for service... that costs an estimated $125 to repair!  Are you kidding me?  That's a ridiculous amount of money to spend when there are other waterproof cameras currently on the market that have better reviews and cost around $150!  It's absolutely insulting that Nikon would try to gouge their customers with exorbitant repair rates when the camera clearly did not function as advertised.  If you look at other reviews, you will notice quite a few people have suffered the same consequences, sustaining water damage after only one use underwater.  That is unacceptable, and Nikon should work harder with their customers to rectify the situation instead of robbing them of even more money.  Apologies if this review turned into a rant, but I'm furious that I paid around $250 for the camera and now Nikon is trying to get me to pay another $125 just to get the camera to work like it was supposed to!Buyer beware!

Reviews.Title: Ugg camera disaster!
Reviews.Author: Bonnie Moses
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for our family trip to Maui. It's only purpose was to take pictures of the family in the water and while snorkeling. After 5 photos in the pool, it started to leak. It fogs up in the lense area and so photos are cloudy. The second try after it dries out was while snorkeling. This time it fogged up so badly on the view screen that I had no idea what I was shooting photos of. So our entire day of snorkeling was not caught on film.... Disappointing! In addition, I tried using the camera before we came on our trip at my daughters swim meet. It takes terrible grainy pics when not in the water. I was so disappointed in its dry land shots that I brought my Sony along on the trip, so thankful for that now! With all the amazing cameras out there, which I own 3 other dry land very good cameras, there is no excuse that a "tough" "waterproof" camera shouldn't work for at least one purpose well. Save your money folks and do your research, people who claim this takes good land photos must not have a very good regular camera, and it sounds like underwater shooting is hit and miss depending on who assembled cameras in the factory on a particular day. Disappointment!

Reviews.Title: Good but be careful in the Ocean
Reviews.Author: ppl
Reviews.Content: I was very happy with the camera, takes great pics both in and out of the water. I have owned a few underwater cameras and I really liked this one.Unfortunately I have to mark it down, not due to the camera per se but it did leak on me when I used it in the Ocean. I was very careful with the seal and only opened and closed it when fully dry (i.e. low humidity) and kept the seal clean. The leak happened when I was using it in the waves. They weren't huge waves but enough to cause leakage that shut down the camera. I had been using it in the water for about 20minutes before the leak and when it shut down I assumed the battery had run flat. Only on inspection did I find small amounts of salt water had got through the seal. It was enough to warrant sending it in for repair.Unfortunately Nikon refused to repair it free of charge which is another reason for the mark down. I understand this though as that would mean the camera was not up to the environment and it is marketed as a very tough camera. The claim "The AW100 can handle all that Mother Nature can throw at it" is a bit of an exaggeration. I was only snorkelling.

Reviews.Title: NOT WATERPROOF
Reviews.Author: James R. Simpson
Reviews.Content: II was looking for a waterproof camera to take snorkeling on our next trip to St. John USVI and after reading the reviews decided on this Nikon AW100 but am sad to say that as soon as I entered the water to start taking some pictures the lens of the camera had fogged up on the inside and it only could  take pictures of the fog on the lens which is no good after leaving it out of the water for a while the fog went away. The camera takes  great pictures but if you are looking for a waterproof camera you better look at a different one.Rick S

Reviews.Title: We really wanted to like this camera
Reviews.Author: MikeCNY
Reviews.Content: We really wanted to like this camera. we've owned two underwater cameras, the Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS2 and now this one. The Lumix failed several times and was repaired each time, until finally, about a month ago, the warranty just paid off the value of the camera. I purchased this camera to replace that one for a trip we just got back from. This camera is being returned because it failed twice during the trip.First time, it lost about 40 or so pictures taken during one of the two tours we went on.  The pictures were there during the day, and the first time we reviewed them, they were all there, but then when my wife went to point out some of the pictures she took later that evening, only 2 of the 40 or so that were taken during the tour were still there.  I had to use file recovery software when I got home from the trip to recover them.  After losing all of those pictures, we bought a new memory card to make sure that the pictures, if they were still there, wouldn't be overwritten by the camera later in our trip.  The pictures taken were great, so I was willing to overlook the lost pictures, assuming the memory card might be bad, it is a couple of years old.  If you want to know how bad this issue is with Nikon cameras, Google retrieving lost pictures from a memory card, you'll find entry after entry by people with Nikon cameras trying to find a way to get pictures back that the camera lost.  I wish I had followed up on some of the reviews saying this was a problem...The next day, while on a second tour, the camera completely froze, no buttons would respond at all, as others have reported in reviews.  We had to remove the battery from it and plug it back in before it would respond again.It is a real shame that this happened since the pictures were great, when we could see them, and the camera worked great, except when it froze and had to be hard booted.  Since both of these things happened within the return period, I am sending the camera back.

Reviews.Title: Love the underwater camera!
Reviews.Author: philephan81
Reviews.Content: We took it for a three week trip in Central America. It was so much fun to use scuba diving, kayaking, swimming, etc.  I highly recommend this product!  One note: the battery was going dead pretty fast, so I shut off the gps system. I think that it kept searching for my location and it was draining the battery. Other than that - it was great!  Took it down to about 30 feet when scuba diving.

Reviews.Title: So Far, Amazing
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth
Reviews.Content: After much research, and some misgivings, I opted to purchase this camera for a month long trip to Hawaii. After reading all the horror stories I was a little leery, but this camera performed very well. I spent 14 days snorkeling, and 1 day scuba diving (to 25 ft), and took the camera with me all of those times. I also had it in the water taking pictures of surfers and kiteboarders, so in all, the camera was in the water about 20 days. It takes great pictures and has a mind-boggling array of features if one is inclined to use them, but it takes really good pictures just on the auto setting. I did use the underwater setting all the times I used it underwater. The main problem I had with the camera was that it did fog up inside the lens when I changed locations - primarily from shade to hot sun. The first time this happened I was in a very dry area and opened the case, it only took about 3 minutes to loose the fog. The other times is was near or in the water - all high humidity areas - and did not open the case. These times it took longer, 10-15min to loose the fog. Being in a very high humidity area it would have been difficult to avoid any moisture inside the camera, but this is my only complaint about the camera. In the future I think I will bring a silicone packet to put in the camera when the battery is charging to get rid of internal moisture. I was very careful to soak the camera in fresh water after each saltwater day, as well as to keep the seal area clean. The day I took the camera scuba diving it worked well, but I would not take it any deeper than I did (25'), as I could see the screen on the back of the camera caving in from the pressure. I am very happy I bought this camera, love the fact I don't have to worry about getting it wet, and would definitely recommend it to others!

Reviews.Title: AMAZING!!! Just like that!
Reviews.Author: Antoine
Reviews.Content: I am speechless with the camera. It is soooooo easy to use, comfortable (at least for my fingers). I expected it to be bigger, but there is no problem with the size since the camera works perfectly.I brought it to Guatemala City and the GPS worked wonderful!Easy to set up,ready to use, instructions of HOW TO AVOID RUIN YOU'RE CAMERA REALLY help, and just as I checked for reviews before the purchase... for the fog you can get on lens... it clearly stated IS NOT A CAMERA ISSUE you have to pull out battery and SD card leave it open to fresh air and the fog dissapears and it happens OBVIOUSLY for the change of temperature... ;)EASY and beautiful pictures. I saved more than $100.00 and no regreats!!!

Reviews.Title: Needs a software update
Reviews.Author: Jason "resevordg"
Reviews.Content: I wanted a point and shoot that could some some snorkeling, and water-sports etc. I looked at the GoPro but I wanted better image quality than they offer.This cool pix AW 100 is good but even the finest quality images offered have way too much JPG compression, and there is a just a bit of chromatic aberrations on the contrasty edges, but I expected the aberrations since it is just a point and shoot and there is a extra glass for the waterproofing. Also the images don't have the best dynamic range, but I also expected that.What I did not expect to see is three things that Nikon can fix with a software update.Here they are:1. The images are over-processed and over sharpened. It's like someone at the factory just pushed the sharpen slider all the way to the right. The images look like they have a layer of frost on them, especially with a noon-day sun. I hope Nikon fixes this.2. Even in the finest mode, the JPGs are over compressed and there are compression artifacts. Memory cards are cheap, and file size is no big deal. If you have to make the camera shoot in jpg just keep the compression at 100 so that I don't have cringe. My iPhone has fewer artifacts. Again this can fixed with a software update - Please Nikon, please fix this.3. Why not have RAW mode. I know it will slow down the response time. But if I hike many miles to see some cool spot, I will have no problem using a slower camera to get a good photograph.As it is now, this camera is great for publishing to FaceBook but I cant really see myself printing many of the photos I take with this :(If Nikon fixes Those three things with a software update, I am sure the images would improve, I would actually print the images and this will be 5+ star camera.P.S. Nikon, if you come out with new version of this camera, an external mic jack and PC strobe sync jack wold be great. It can be done while maintaining waterproofness.

Reviews.Title: Solid Camera, But Has Limits.
Reviews.Author: T. J. Daugherty
Reviews.Content: I've now used this camera in the swimming pool, rafting, hiking, fishing, and it has even gone to the South China Sea.  So far it has held up well in dry, wet, and underwater conditions.  It is a good durable camera from my experience.This camera can take some great photos - some coming close to equaling my DSLR.  However, I've found it wise to take more shots than you need, because it can also lose focus, over-expose, etc.  Maybe 20% of the shots are sketchy (in auto mode) - which is probably more or less in line with phone cameras and other mid-level point-n-shoots.The interface and settings menus are generally easy to navigate.  I think many of these point-n-shoot cameras have tried to cram in so many functions that at times navigating the menus is a bit quirky, but I've kept it mostly in Automatic settings so I can't say I've probed too deeply on all the functions (using my DSLR for more advanced photography).I was actually surprised at how good the video worked.  Combined with the waterproof aspect of the camera it is great fun to take with you on fishing, boating, and swimming adventures.  I've made some fun short movies of me and the dogs playing in the pool - including underwater.No problems with the battery life.  I did by one back-up for longer trips, but haven't come close to going through two charged batteries in muliple week long trips.  My sense is you can get about three days of vacation pics (short video) on one charge.Really my only complaint is that my thumb/finger is showing up on many photos and videos.  The ergonomics are not conducive to shooting with both hands (specifically your left hand).  Wouldn't be a deal killer for me, but definitely cost it a star rating.  Why not swap the lens location with the GPS towards the middle?In summary, this is a darn good camera for what its designed for.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: 1of5_in_Frisco
Reviews.Content: Great Camera, Great Pictures, Good Video, Cool GPS option...  The only downside is you can't charge the battery from a USB cable.  You have to use Nikon's adapter which means you have to carry more stuff around...  So if you forget your charger your kinda screwed...

Reviews.Title: Rugged, great battery, poor image quality
Reviews.Author: M. Wise "Marc"
Reviews.Content: I bought this to keep with my fishing vest for an always available, rugged, waterproof camera for fishing and outdoor pictures.  I ended up using it for both fishing and carrying it in my briefcase so I would always have a camera with me.  After using it for some time I am pleasantly surprised about the battery life and responsiveness of the camera.  It has not been dropped, abused or submerged but has stood up to many, many miles in an overstuffed briefcase and/or backpack and has held up really well.  That is the good.  Unfortunately the picture quality is just horrible and grainy even though it has always been used at the lowest ISO possible.  The pictures really are poor compared to any number of other point and shoot cameras.  Even my iPhone 4s while only half the pixel count is significantly better.  Nikon should reduce the pixel density, increase the lens size and try again.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Singe
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a recent trip to Hawaii.  I needed something that would be ok for snorkeling as well as something that could easily be carried in a cargo pocket and this one rocked!  I love the easy settings, including 'Underwater' which captured some fantastic pictures of the fish in Hanauma Bay.It's also the best point and shoot camera I've ever owned for capturing action photos.  Pictures of fish at the aquarium, without flash, look like a screensaver instead of something I took!  I also used it at a football game, playing with the zoom feature for close-ups of the field.  Even fully zoomed, the action pics were not blurry.And the 'Panorama' setting has an easy 180 and 360 degree option which made for some amazing photos from all the scenic views atop the various volcanos.I haven't played with the GPS option yet or even explored the vast majority of other settings but I'm very pleased with the Coolpix so far.  I bought it in Fall 2012 and didn't have the same issues that other reviewers have mentioned when the camera hits the water so maybe Nikon has sorted that part out.Highly, highly recommend this camera if you need a good one for outdoor adventures.

Reviews.Title: great weather proof camera
Reviews.Author: surfing terry
Reviews.Content: I buy several cameras a year just because of rough use and salt water spray.  The bright color is very valuable when this camera fell off my horse in the snow. The next pack train on the trail several days later saw the bright color in the snow and picked it up for me.  I often have a camera with me on the ocean and it is  often covered with salt water and slime, this camera is tough.  I just wash it up and start taking pictures.  This camera will be with me anywhere and anyplace, I like it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Product!
Reviews.Author: John Puopolo
Reviews.Content: I was nervous when I bought this because I read reviews of it leaking and it working then not working. I wanted this for a vacation I was taking to the Bahamas since I planned on going snorkeling. I ordered it really close to the day of departure so I was crossing my fingers that on my test it was no defective. I submerged it in my bathtub and took pictures of things and it worked great. I let it dry and powered it on again the next morning to make sure it was functional. My concern was salt water so I was uneasy still. I took it out in the waters of the Bahamas took videos and pictures in the water and it worked great. video was incredible and pictures were as well. I submerged it as the directions state in water to rinse it took it out and let it dry. I powered it on the next day and it worked great. I am thinking some people may have issue because the seal for the battery is very fragile as the directions state. The suggest opening the door and holding it upside down so any particles such as sand or whatever do not stay in the seal. If you close the air tight seal with an obstruction then water can seep in. Design flaw? no just reality. Make sure you do not close anything in the seal such as camera strap or sand and the seal should not be damaged. as a precaution I have affixed my camera strap to the opposite side of the door to avoid such a mishap. Anyways its a great product and I have yet to have any issues. To the people who are saying it takes crap pictures underwater I say this. Murky waters will not take awesome pictures. I have used underwater surveillance equipment in waters that are dirty and even with intense lights designed to offset murky waters you still cant see anything so make sure a) your camera is set to underwater mode and b) make sure your not in dirty water.

Reviews.Title: Nearly perfect adventure camera
Reviews.Author: Steve H
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Nikon AW100 after researching the waterproof pocket size offerings of the dominant manufacturers who have similar cameras.  Through the reviews found online, and comparing the specifications, the Nikon seemed a bit too good to be true.  It was spec'd to have higher resolution than the rest (16MP), better zoom (only 5X, but better than 3X or 4X of competitors), and it is lighter.  I was a little concerned with the $300 price tag, but I figure the waterproof capability alone saves me from destroying cameras or having to deal with dry bags/boxes to protect fragile equipment is well worth the investment.When I received the camera, I dug in and checked out all the accessories.  The reason I call it a "near perfect" camera is because you have to remove the battery to charge it.  If you could recharge it through the USB cable that is used to offload the photos, I would definitely remove the "nearly".  The charger included only works on AC power, so if you are on a long adventure, you will either need an aftermarket charger that works on 12VDC, or USB, or make sure you have plenty of extra batteries to get you through.  I found that a battery will last through an active day of taking photos and videos, so I would recommend one battery per day with an extra if you are a real shutterbug  If you aren't constantly turning it on and off and snapping shots, you can obviously get by with less.  It remains to be seen if there is a loss of capacity in the Li-ion batteries as they age.  Typically this cell chemistry does well over time.Right out of the box, I got the battery charged and installed it, and couldn't wait to get it wet.  I turned it on, and filled up a large tumbler with water and plunged it in.  After all, if it is going to fail on me, I want it to happen at home, not out on the trail when I am depending upon it to capture the memories of a lifetime.  I let it soak for a little while and was comfortable that this little gem was definitely at least splash proof.  That weekend, I went out kayak fishing offshore with some friends.  I was still learning how to use many of the functions, so I accidentally left it on several times, and other rookie mistakes, but it held up perfectly and I got some good photos and video of fish being caught and released.A couple weeks later, the reason I made this purchase came up and I headed for Montana.  I learned more about the functions and the panorama function was again worth the cost of the camera.  When you are in the midst of enormous vistas that you have no idea how to capture, this mode is the best way to try to show your friends what you experienced.  This camera takes fantastic panorama shots that capture mountain views better than I have ever pieced together in Photoshop.  One click of the button and pan 180 or 360 degrees and you get the whole thing holding the camera landscape or portriat.The macro mode is also very good.  I took many photos of wildflowers, of which, the ones where I remembered the macro mode, turned out fabulous.  I also took some great shots of a flyfishing lure in front of a sunrise that look like postcards.  Having the camera halfway submerged is the only way to get the angle and the sharpness that I achieved.  Knowinig a few basics about how to frame a photo and a good camera that figures out all the little details while protecting itself from the elements makes for some amazing memories to share with friends and family.Some of the mountain lakes filled with fish were a great opportunity to video some of them swimming around.  I started the video, and sank the camera into the icy water and followed the fish for some HD video that is hard to beat by National Geographic.  The camera handled everything without a hitch.  It was even blown off a rock a couple times while I was trying to take a self portriat using a small tripod.  A four foot tumble down a boulder into the rocks didn't even scratch it.This is a tough camera, for those who need a waterproof camera that is light, reliable, and easy to use.  It is the point and shoot that you have been dreaming of.Get out there!

Reviews.Title: Impressed but couple of flaws
Reviews.Author: Anthony E Hornak
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera a few months ago and take it with me everywhere.  I love using it and I love the comfort factor that I can hand it to my kids to use without having to hoover over them.  For me the Pro's outweigh the Cons.  This camera is loads of fun.Cons:- BIG CON:  Owner manual states to replace the seal on the door annually.  I am ok with this but when I called Nikon to find out how much the annual maintenance would cost me they told me I had to mail the camera in for an estimate, hmm. They would NOT give me a price over the phone nor was I allowed to contact the place in New York where my camera would be shipped to for work. Everything would have to be done by mail. Why would a company who mass manufactures a product not know how much the seal/part cost and how much labor is required to perform a periodic maintenance that they themselves outlines as necessary?  Secondly, why would they expect their customer to mail their AW100 camera in to an unknown facility; that the consumer is not allowed to contact or speak with; to later have an "estimate" mailed to them of work the mysterious people deemed necessary when your camera was working just fine to begin with.  3 stars for this alone.- Is not fog resistance.  Guess you can't have everything- Performance is poor indoors/low light settings- When using the Flash the camera can take a few extra seconds to refresh.  Not to be exact but I have seen ~5sec; could have been due to low battery.- I may need to mess with the setting a bit more but I do happen to get blurry pics when trying to catch my kids in motion.  Auto focus lags when within a few feet range ie: 22ft - 6ft or so to give an example/not exact.- Video mode the auto focus is non-existent when zooming in.Pros:- This is an OUTDOOR camera.  Taking pics outdoors is where it thrives. =D This is why I carry it everywhere with me because the pictures do come out very beautifully.- Zoom is acceptable for fix lenses.- Slow mode camera setting - very cool. Don't have a use for it yet but still cool.-  Battery life is descent - last all day.  Going to buy a spare battery just because I constantly used the camera and video mode definitely takes more juice. Love my videos.- Nice design - very compact and sleek.- Video mode is cool out of the water and in the water.  Love it.Suggestion:- If you like going out in the water a lot whether at the beach, lake, on a boat buy a floating device for your camera.  I have one. It is easy to take off.- IMPORTANT: When not in use OPEN up the battery door - the seal is made of rubber and even though it is a "rugged" camera it needs a little TLC.  To ensure a good seal you need to allow the rubber to expand every once in a while instead of that yellow seal always staying compress when the door is closed.- Since the seal is rubber make sure it does not dry out.  If it is looking like it might - treat it.- Place/buy scratch resistance screen protector for the back of the camera.- Also makes sure that the smallest granule of dirt is not between the seal and the camera before closing the battery door. Bad voodoo.Food for Thought:- I have bought some UV filters and a Macro lens for the camera.  I will let you know how it goes but they are available.- Need to figure out how to get the water to fully bead off of the lens.  Didn't have the issue till recently.  I have found it hard to take pics with water spots blocking the image I am trying to capture and usually I am all wet so I do not have anything "dry" to wipe the lens - catch 22.  May try RainX but still thinking about a solution.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera - Battery life could have been better.
Reviews.Author: SJ
Reviews.Content: We really like this camera. Kids are having a blast with it in the pool and water parks. So far we've used this camera under water at least 6 times. No issues with water leaking or anything. Kids dropped it couple of times too. But the camera handled it pretty well.I wish the battery life was better on this camera though. You definitely need a spare battery.Also the lens should have had some kind of coating to keep the water off.

Reviews.Title: Started leaking on 1st snorkeling trip
Reviews.Author: kainaat420
Reviews.Content: First visit out snorkeling with maximum depth of 2 feet the camera started fogging up inside the lens. Let it dry in the sun and fog cleared ; next snorkeling trip after 10 minutes in the water the lens again fogged up and the pictures showed it... sent back to Amazon as a return. After reading lots of reviews it seems majority of the underwater cameras (even the TOUGH ones) all have this problem... reivews of Lumix Ts4 say the same thing.So looking around for which one to get now... maybe one with a proper underwater housing.

Reviews.Title: Exceptional Value for price - a Must Have
Reviews.Author: Tonsies
Reviews.Content: I bought the Nikon coolpix aw100 on a whim to take with us on our trip to Oahu Hawaii.  It is our first day back home and I'm astounded at what we captured using this little camera. It's ridiculously easy to use, the settings are intuitive and the video is fabulous too! Here is a quick list of why we loved this camera:1. Waterproof, Shock Proof2. Ease of Use3. Quality of photos and videos4. Price PointYou will not be disappointed! I'll add some photos of our trip, so keep your eyes open.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix from Amazon dropped from Harley Motorcycle
Reviews.Author: KEO
Reviews.Content: Dropped this little camera from a Harley Davison motorcycle at 50 mph.  Went back 1/4 mile and picked it up from the gravel at the side of the road.  2 dents, works perfectly. Definitely needs the uv filter kit here in Colorado.

Reviews.Title: Really nice!
Reviews.Author: TimC
Reviews.Content: We are very pleased with the AW100. We purchased it before heading to the Riviera Maya. Having a pocket sized camera that worked to film in 1080P cave diving, snapping pictures of beautiful fish in the brackish waters of the lagoon, sea turtles in the Carribean Sea, and still producing great pictures of our resort, landscape, animals, people and the beach was incredible. The quality is every bit as good as our other point and shoot cameras if not better. There were moments I missed my DSLR, but this was a vacation and I get tired of lugging around that equipment like I'm there to document rather than to enjoy. This lightweight waterproof camera was perfect. Having the GPS built in was really cool too.

Reviews.Title: Use it outdoors, not in the studio!
Reviews.Author: JP
Reviews.Content: I am amazed at this camera! I just completed a 5K mudrun with this camera looped around my shoulder. I swam through mud, ran over obstacles, ran in 95 degree weather and it survived with amazing video and images. In fact, it was completely covered in mud that I was unable to clear the lens half way through the race, rendering it useless. After the race I doused it with a water bottle and took a few more quality shots. When I arrived home I washed it in the sink, let it dry and cracked the memory card compartment open. It was like brand new. Data transferred perfectly and been checking it the last few days for operation and it is still working perfectly.I 100% recommend this product. It won't replace a DSLR, but for extreme memories this is it. I opted for this camera over a go pro for more useability. It has the standard tripod screw hole on the bottom and I've looked up some decent camera mounts for it, so they're available. And, it's a terrific point and shoot with many features.Tip: Learn how to use the camera. If your pictures or videos are not coming out the way you want then there is a setting you are missing. If you haven't drained the battery at least through two full charges playing with all the features and settings and read the manual, then you're going to miss your shot.The macro setting is amazing. It will focus on an object touching the lens. Image stablization works well when standing still and does its best while running holding in your hand. The video auto focus is a little slow during drastic changes in depth.

Reviews.Title: be very careful
Reviews.Author: curly
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera specifically because it was waterproof.  Went snorkeling with it... carefully dried it off...waited till the next day to open the battery door...thought the battery died, when I did a flood water came out. end of camera.Update: I returned the camera to Nikon and they promptly replaced it... very happy with their customer service.  I thought the camera was easy to use and small enough to bring everywhere. Not sure if I will let it get wet again.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera for water sports
Reviews.Author: Kevin T.
Reviews.Content: This is the first Nikon I've owned.  I've traditionally been a Canon user, but the reviews on this model finally tempted me into purchasing it for my 21 yr old son who is an avid kayaker and marine biology college student about to make a 2 week trip to Costa Rica.  He is also an avid ocean kayaker, so the camera got a workout this weekend as he paddled 7 miles offshore.  The camera took fantastic photos and was easy for him to handle even while wearing kayak gloves.  We put a Chums float strap on the camera and it kept the camera both sink-proof as well as easy to find with the bright yellow strap color.  The 1080P video is vivid and the stills are beyond words.  Nikon really built this camera like a tank.  It is shock proof, which is a necessity for boating or other water sports.  For those worried that the camera might be difficult to learn to use, he had the basics literally in 10 minutes, and was a pro at using it in 30 minutes.  It does not require an in-depth knowledge of photography to take great shots with this camera.  All in all, I give this model 5 starts.

Reviews.Title: Overall very dissapointed, some good, mostly bad.
Reviews.Author: jwrichte
Reviews.Content: I recently purchased the Nikon AW100 for the exciting year that I have planned. I love photography but would by no means call myself an expert. I purchased this product expecting the kind of quality that I have seen from my friends Nikon Cameras. I have trips planned this year for both Negril and white water rafting and thought that this would be a fun investment.We recently just returned from our trip to negril. I used the camera everyday as my walk around camera. On the first day I used it for a quick swim in the ocean, a tour of the hotel grounds, and a few shots at dinner. The next day when we went to go on our snorkeling trip I jumped in the ocean and the lens instantly fogged up with condensation under the lens. It was about 84 degrees outside and the ocean was around 75-80 degrees so there was a rapid temperature change but not that big of a change. Also there should have been no moisture under the lens to begin with.The rest of the trip the condensation spots would just magically appear. I have video where I was in the middle of walking around the and suddenly the top half of the lens is completely fogged up. Here is a link to a video of the camera just fogging up in the middle of shooting a video....[...]Additionally the paint on the buttons is already rubbing off after just one week of use.The video quality of the camera is good, the outdoor picture quality is decent, the indoor picture quality is awful. The camera has very low IQ.I can't tell you how disappointed I am that this camera is a bust. I wish I had gone with the Canon D10 or the Panasonic. Don't make the same mistake I did, look elsewhere!

Reviews.Title: Great camera and great service
Reviews.Author: Lance Huffington
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for use while snorkeling in Maui, I've used it underwater for 4 days now and it takes great pictures. As a land camera it has all the perfect pre-set settings so anyone can make great pictures. It's that easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Alpentalic
Reviews.Content: I own the Nikon Coolpix L110 and that camera takes amazing photos! The main reason I have cameras is to take photos and videos of my friends and I snowboarding/hiking.
